abstract.p: Joseph Michael DeShan, fifth trade teacher in South Jersey, returns to class three weeks after being suspended because of news reports that he impregnated 15-year-old girl while he was priest in Roman Catholic Diocese of Brideport, Conn, in 1988 and 1989; Dr Salvatore J Illuzi, superintendent of schools in Cinnaminson, NJ, says he and two lawyers for district determined that DeShan had neither violated any administrative rules nor appeared vulnerable to criminal charges because Connecticut's statute of limitations on sexual assault is two years to report crime and five years to prosecute it (M)

block.p: A fifth-grade teacher in South Jersey returned to class yesterday, three weeks after he was suspended because of news reports that he had impregnated a 15-year-old girl while he was a priest in Connecticut.

The teacher, Joseph Michael DeShan, was placed on paid administrative leave from his job in Cinnaminson, N.J., on April 12, said Dr. Salvatore J. Illuzi, the superintendent of schools. The leave came after Connecticut newspapers reported that Mr. DeShan had a sexual relationship with the girl in 1988 and 1989, while he was a priest in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport.

A fifth-grade teacher in South Jersey returned to class yesterday, three weeks after he was suspended because of news reports that he had impregnated a 15-year-old girl while he was a priest in Connecticut.

The teacher, Joseph Michael DeShan, was placed on paid administrative leave from his job in Cinnaminson, N.J., on April 12, said Dr. Salvatore J. Illuzi, the superintendent of schools. The leave came after Connecticut newspapers reported that Mr. DeShan had a sexual relationship with the girl in 1988 and 1989, while he was a priest in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport.

Dr. Illuzi said that he and two lawyers for the district had determined that Mr. DeShan had neither violated any administrative rules nor appeared vulnerable to criminal charges because Connecticut's statute of limitations on sexual assault is two years to report a crime and five years to prosecute it.
Dr. Illuzi said he told Mr. DeShan's lawyer on Wednesday that the teacher could return to his job immediately.

''He did come back today, and he was very positively received by his students and his colleagues,'' the superintendent said, adding that the district's review had not touched on the substance of Mr. DeShan's actions.
The woman who made the accusation, now 28, lives in Connecticut with the 12-year-old daughter she said she had with Mr. DeShan, The Associated Press reported.

Dr. Illuzi said Mr. DeShan, 42, a husband and father of two other children, is a popular, excellent teacher whose five-year history with the district is otherwise unblemished. Dr. Illuzi said the teacher would accompany fifth graders, parents and other teachers, on a camping trip in two weeks.

Cardinal Edward M. Egan of the Archdiocese of New York was the bishop in Bridgeport at the time the woman said the affair occurred. The archdiocese and the Bridgeport diocese have issued a joint statement saying that though Cardinal Egan was told of the relationship after Mr. DeShan disclosed it, the girl's age had not been revealed.
''DeShan testified that he had had 'a monogamous relationship with a woman' -- not a minor,'' the statement said.
The dioceses said that Bridgeport officials became aware of a relationship in 1994, when Mr. DeShan began proceedings to leave the priesthood.
Dr. Illuzi said he had received 13 letters and e-mail messages from parents in support of Mr. DeShan's return, and 2 opposed. One couple asked that their daughter not be placed in his class.
Dr. Illuzi said the teacher did not want to comment. Mr. DeShan's lawyer, Steven R. Cohen, did not return calls.
Mayor William Kollar of Cinnaminson said parents seemed untroubled by the reports about Mr. DeShan's past.
''If indeed, if the community has given him this much support,'' he said, ''let him go ahead.''
